content.webTitle: Tony Birch on The White Girl: ‘No Aboriginal person I know is intact’

fields.headline: Tony Birch on The White Girl: ‘No Aboriginal person I know is intact’
fields.bodyText: Other writers may cringe to learn that Tony Birch wrote the first draft of his new novel, The White Girl, in about eight weeks. Birch’s other novels – Blood (2011) and Ghost River (2015), both acclaimed – also read like they were written with ease, so commanding is the authorial voice; so linear of plot, and authentic of character and emotional resonance. But The White Girl, Birch says, came still faster and easier. Birch says he’s most pleased with this latest, as we sit in Mario’s, a cafe that is as quintessentially Fitzroy as Birch. At 62, the novelist is also a short story-writer, poet, academic historian, climate justice-Indigenous rights activist who grew up in inner-city Melbourne with a rich Aboriginal, Barbadian (convict), Irish and Afghani heritage. “To me it’s the most balanced [novel]. And this is going to frighten some people – I literally wrote the first draft in about two months,” he says. The White Girl is a black and white story about Australian colonialism’s malevolent legacies, and the courage, strength and dignity of Indigenous resistance. It’s a story about strong women, with whom Birch’s life has been blessed. It is also a profound allegory of good and evil, and a deep exploration of human interaction, black and white, alternately beautiful and tender, cruel and unsettling. The plot begins in the 1960s in fictitious Deane, a country town whose physical, historic and bureaucratic character might place it in southern Queensland, north-western New South Wales or Victoria, where Aboriginal people were at the whim of “protectors”, be they police or missions, and from whom they required permission for most freedoms, including travel. But Deane, a dying colonial town on a drying river whose waters have been stolen for whitefella agriculture, has national resonance – just like racist colonial legacies. Deane is anywhere. Deane is everywhere. The story revolves around Aboriginal Odette Brown, a Deane resident since childhood who cares for Sissy, a granddaughter conceived in rape by a white pastoralist, Joe Kane, for whom Odette once worked as a domestic. Odette’s daughter, Lila, traumatised by her violation and unable to cope with life as a mother, fled to the big city, leaving behind Sissy, the white girl of Birch’s title. It’s a multiple quest. First, to the city for a desired reconciliation between Odette, Lila and Sissy so as to prevent the new town cop, Sergeant Lowe – state-custodian of all Aboriginal people in his district – from taking (white) Sissy from her (black) grandma carer. Second, to mete out some sort of natural justice to the Kanes, whose colonial pioneering dream settlement has descended into decrepitude, depravity and poverty. Other characters about Deane embody the varying sympathies of non-Indigenous Australians to the Aboriginal postcolonial plight. We have the retiring alcoholic copper Bill Shea, whose story becomes the tragedy of inaction. Birch also gives us junkyard owner Henry Lamb (a name can evoke so much that dozens of pages can’t) who became “touched” after a knock on the head as a kid, found himself befriended by the Indigenous kids and endured a lifetime of ostracism – and gained more emotional intelligence than Deane’s collected white populace. “I wanted to write a character who ... is intellectually challenged in some ways, but I hope I didn’t write him in a patronising way,” Birch says. “He’s much more emotionally intelligent than most people around him.” Henry and the Kanes clash, their resolution a deft dramatic crescendo of The White Girl. There is also a Jewish town doctor possessed of natural empathy towards Odette, and old Millie Khan: Odette’s lifelong Aboriginal friend who is also married to a Muslim Afghan cameleer. Birch’s great grandfather on his mother’s side was an Afghani, Bouta Khan, from the Punjab. “He came to Australia in the 1890s, and he had to go through the terrible process of getting an exemption from the Immigration Act [under the white Australia policies] in the 20th century so that he could take my grandmother back to the Punjab so she could meet his family ... there were three of those families who settled in Fitzroy,” he says. “They had their own mosque which ran out of a terrace house. And they were really great people. “I’ve always felt for that man because he was a really devout non-drinker, hard-worker, never been in trouble with the police and yet he had to go through the humiliation of getting an exemption.” I’ve met novelists who ponder if their ancestries and life experiences are sufficiently “interesting” to adequately serve their creativity. Birch could never be among them. Expelled for the second time in a year, he left school early: “At the age of 15 I began a ‘career’ riding a pushbike as a telegram boy.” Birch later spent a decade as a firefighter. He went to the University of Melbourne, as a mature-age student, at 30. In 2003 he was awarded the Chancellor’s Medal for the best PhD in Arts. He is now the Bruce McGuinness research fellow at Victoria University, where he applies skills as a writer to climate change research and to advancing justice for those most impacted by it: Indigenous communities and people on society’s margins. Birch is a writer with a profound gift for language and human insight. He writes with razor’s edge emotional clarity and empathy about people and place – especially on those Australian margins, rural and urban. The White Girl showcases his gift. He’s a knockabout bloke who, despite diminutive height, exudes a formidable physical presence and has something about him of the featherweight boxer – not surprising, perhaps, given his fighting antecedents. Birch’s great grandfather was James “Prince” Moodie, transported from Barbados to Tasmania. “His crime, for which he was transported for 14 years, was listed as ‘disobedience’ – of which I’m proud,” Birch says. James Moodie’s descendants included Les Moodie, a lightweight who often pursued more lucrative boxing prizes in Sydney where, Birch says, he was subject to extreme racism and announced as “the coffee-coloured coon from Melbourne”. The White Girl is a novel with national Indigenous themes: colonial oppression, dispossession, the stolen generations, generational violence against Aboriginal people. “I’ve never met an Aboriginal person who doesn’t have a story of that sort of loss [through the stolen generations] somewhere in their family. No Aboriginal person I know is completely intact because of that … Everyone is missing someone, and someone in that family has got to carry that repository of memory,” he says. It was also always going to be a book about strong black women, he says. “I knew at the outset that I was going to write a novel that could reach Aboriginal women. Again, for all the family experience and all the material I’d read in the public records office and what I’d heard from other people, I was determined to write a really strong, central female character. And really to celebrate the courage and heroics of Aboriginal women,” he says. Birch is unsure if his novel, for all the historical weight he has managed to weave so lightly into the narrative, will dispel the ignorance, much of it wilful, that still characterises Australia’s refusal to process such a dark, violent past. “I think there’s this continuum cycle of push-pull around what we might call enlightenment. And I think what happens in colonial societies is that we never get to move into a postcolonial state of being … and we can’t until we have a much longer period of contemplation, of ethical thinking, of dignified relationships across different divides,” he says. “I’m really proud of this book. But I’m not confident that any book or piece of art has the ability to fundamentally shift many people. When people, for example, talk about climate change and the role of writers and artists – I believe in that. But if people ask, ‘Do we write more climate change fiction?’ I say, ‘No – we fucking get down on the picket line’.” • The White Girl by Tony Birch is out now through UQP
